ResponsesInList.Title: Embed Player for student responses to CloudPoodll Question in Quiz?
ResponsesInList.Text: I'm experimenting with the Cloud Poodll question type, and I'm noticing that when a teacher goes to the Quiz Results page and views Responses, there are hyperlinks to the student recordings, rather than having the filters turn them into play-able files.  Is that deliberate?  I would love to specify the tiny player skin on this page.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Embed Player for student responses to CloudPoodll Question in Quiz?
ResponsesInList.Text: HI Carly, Right now those hyperlinks can not be turned into play-able files. If you hover your mouse over the link you will see that it actually points to a reviewquestion.php page for that attempt and question. If it was a link to a .mp3 file then we could turn it into a player. Sorry.

ResponsesInList.Title: Less strict settings in Speechcards / Minilesson?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello everybody, hello Justin, We have been using Poodll, this great tool for language teaching, for four years now, and it's really fabulous. There are so many things you can do with it, especially get students of foreign languages to speak, which is not an easy task given that they are often very numerous in a university class... Wo use Read Aloud a lot, but I'm new to Minilessons, and haven't been using the widgets much either. So here's the question: in some cases, like in Minilesson or Speechcards, Poodll seems to consider my answers as incorrect how ever hard I try. In the Speechcards items I get like two stars out of three but I'm stuck there (I would love to use this to create structural exercises like Does he like it?|Yes he does - that's a great additional possibility!). I can't see any settings to configure the way it is graded, like I do in Read Aloud - would anyone know if that's possible, and how to do it? Thank you!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Less strict settings in Speechcards / Minilesson?
ResponsesInList.Text: The developper answered this: one can use Transcriber :=> Guided STT (Poodll) instead of the default. That worked great for me!

ResponsesInList.Title: VIdeoEasy disable video autoplay
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi I have multiple videos in a course page and all run during loading. I want to disable autoplay and how would i do that? Thanks

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: VIdeoEasy disable video autoplay
ResponsesInList.Text: If these videos are being played via the VideoEasy filter, then the answer to this question depends on the template that they are being played with. As far as I know none of the video templates autoplay by default. Which template is being used to handle those videos? You can find this out by looking at the file extension handlers section of the VideoEasy general settings page. This is under Site Admin ->plugins -> filters -> Video Easy And what version is that template? Or is it modified from the default? The template's settings page should tell you that. That is in the same location of the site administration as the General settings page

ResponsesInList.Title: Is PoodLL free or not?
ResponsesInList.Text: Is part of it free?  or only on a trial basis?  I am looking for something on Moodle to let students record voice and video and some other stuff that PoodLL can do but I don't need the sophisticated abilities that PoodLL has for assessing English.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is PoodLL free or not?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Tom There are free Poodll plugins(Generico, Video Easy, Atto Subtitle ..) . But Poodll for audio and video recording is not free. If you just need basic audio and video recording and do not have a budget, Moodle has RecordRTC for recording off the toolbar.

ResponsesInList.Title: Privacy (Poodll Cloud)
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, We are planning to use Poodll and we are specially interested in automatic phonetic correction which is a great feature. I understand the technology is based on Amazon software and data are stoured in the cloud. Can you tell me if this data (students voices) is acced by third parties, Amazon for instance, where the servers are (ie under what laws) /what kind of privacy policiy is applied? Thank you very much for your help!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Privacy (Poodll Cloud)
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Ulrike The data that is sent and stored on Amazon is just voice data. Usernames, email addresses and even the Moodle userid are not stored there. You have a choice of servers, Tokyo, USA (north east), Sydney, Dublin. If you use the Dublin server then it is the EU and GDPR applies. Poodll has a privacy policy, here: https://support.poodll.com/en/support/solutions/articles/19000079274-poodll-user-data-and-gdpr Note also that Poodll supports the Moodle Privacy API so you can manage your requirements using that. I hope that helps

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Privacy (Poodll Cloud)
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Justin, Yes, indeed - thank you very much for your answer (and the good news)! Ulrike

ResponsesInList.Title: Warning -dumb question
ResponsesInList.Text: Moodle 3.72 query This looks fabulous - but just a little worried about storage implications with 10,000 students. 1. Is the teachers marking Audio or video feedbakc hosted on the same server of offloaded elsewhere? 2. If it is on the moodle HTML server does this terrific tool allow the video or audio files to be hosted else where off server? eg free file hosting services? 3. MOST IMPORTANTLY - does this have an expiry for the feedback files to be stored - or to auto-delete after playback by the learner (I know what you're thinking "this message will self destruct" etc) but  I need to know about lifecycle management of rich media as 4 meg feedback x 10-20 feedbacks per year x 1000 (never mind) 10000 students is a concern... Any and all feedback welcome (especially if your answers follow the 1,2,3 numbering!!) Dom

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Warning -dumb question
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Dom, I know we have talked recently over email. But let me answer here too. Sorry to be  a bit late. 1) Either. Cloud Poodll saves them in the Poodll's cloud. Classic Poodll saves them in your Moodle's data directory. 2) You can not configure 3rd party storage in Poodll. But you do have the basic choice outlined in 1) 3) Cloud Poodll has configurable file expiry at the site or activity level (depending on the plugin). Classic Poodll does not. Its a good idea though.

ResponsesInList.Title: Read Aloud - title change not reflected in gradebook setup
ResponsesInList.Text: I noticed something strange today in 3.5 - when I change the title of an existing Read Aloud activity, I DO see the change take place on the course page. However, the OLD name still appears in the grade book setup. Even if I edit the activity on the grsdebook set up page, the old name is shown as the title, but if I then go and edit the activity from the course page, it displays the new name as the title. Ever seen something like that?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Read Aloud - title change not reflected in gradebook setup
ResponsesInList.Text: Hmm. Its probably to do with caching. When you edit it from the course page, Moodle likely refreshes the cached activity names. Presumably we could also do that in the activity itself.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Read Aloud - title change not reflected in gradebook setup
ResponsesInList.Text: While in gradebook setup, I purged my browser cache and moodle cache (click the "purge all caches" button in Site administration / ▶︎ Development / ▶︎ Purge all caches . So if this is being oddly behaved, I'll open up a support ticket. Just wanted to see if there was something on my end I could do to self correct.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Read Aloud - title change not reflected in gradebook setup
ResponsesInList.Text: Ok so if I click edit - edit settings in Gradebook set up , AND THEN click save, then the new titles gets pushed to the grade book. This work around works for the time being.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: PoodLL Widget - Display a Grade

Possibly you could use a block like this: https://moodle.org/plugins/block_my_grades (never tried it ... looks old) or extend the Poodll filter to pull a grade if required. ResponsesInList.Title: PoodLL Feedback tool - only audio available
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi everyone, I just configured the PoodLL assignment feedback tool, and the audio feedback is there and working well.  I don't have a video option, however, and I believe I should also be able to submit video feedback just like audio.  I checked and double-checked my configurations, but can't seem to find anything out of sorts. Can someone direct me how to enable the video Feedback PoodLL?  Thanks! David

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: PoodLL Feedback tool - only audio available
ResponsesInList.Text: Have you been to Site administration > Plugins > Activity modules > Assignment > Feedback plugins > Feedback PoodLL, and made sure that for, Recorders to enable, you have Video Recorder enabled? The other place to check is edit your assignment activity, scroll down to the Feedback types, and for PoodLL Recorder Type, set it to Video Recorder.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: PoodLL Feedback tool - only audio available
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks, AL - that's exactly what I was missing.  I appreciate the help on such a simple question! Is there a way to dynamically (i.e., within the assignment feedback screen) switch between audio and video as an option for feedback? I went to the gear to shut off the webcam, but I don't see a way to turn that off (as a way to preserve the video option, but use only audio for a once-off, for example). Cheers, David

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: PoodLL Feedback tool - only audio available
ResponsesInList.Text: I don't think there is any way to switch except for going to the edit page for the assignment, and changing it there. Of course, if you do that, it would change it for all grading after that. A couple of things you might try: If you have the PoodLL Record Anywhere, see if you can record directly into the text box for feedback. Might not be able to do if that box is not set to allow any type of media insert/ upload . Another possibility if you have the PoodLL Repository set it up is to set the assignment to allow for feedback files. Then go through the steps to upload a file, but select the Poodll repository, make your audio or video recording, and then upload it. That's one of the things I used to do before retiring so I presume it might still work.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: PoodLL Feedback tool - only audio available
ResponsesInList.Text: Good stuff - thanks AL.  I'll give these both a try.  I've done some basic LMS admin stuff before, but not on Moodle.  So, I'm new to the Moodle game.  I appreciate your time and good suggestions, and will get with our engineers to have those other PoodLL tools installed (I've seen them, but hadn't thought about incorporating more of them).  Cheers and thanks for a good first post conversation, David.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: PoodLL Feedback tool - only audio available
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi David Al is  spot on with all his advice. Right now there is no elegant way to do adhoc video feedback when audio is selected as the Poodll feedback type. Its a top idea though. We are working on a new plugin a bit like this, and we might just add that feature in.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: PoodLL Feedback tool - only audio available
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Justin.  I used AL's suggestions and that worked perfectly - to turn on the option I want in the Feedback Type within the named Assignment.  Indeed, it'd be great to be able to also do that on-the-fly within that feedback area of the grading screen (or, at the least, keep it as video feedback, but be able to turn off the video real-time).  I look forward to seeing what plugin you are working on! Cheers, David

ResponsesInList.Title: Poodll Recording Question behavior & feedback
ResponsesInList.Text: Is it possible to work with Poodll recording quiz questions with either of these question behaviors? Immediate Feedback Interactive with Multiple tries At the moment, I use Poodll for an activity where students record an answer to a question and then compare their recorded answer to  to a text model in generalfeedback. This is done using Deferred Feedback after answering all questions. But it would be great if students could check their answer after each question, before moving on.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Poodll Recording Question behavior & feedback
ResponsesInList.Text: I think this could work, in the same way that it is possible to hear the current submission in the assignment. But right now it doesn't do this.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Poodll Recording Question behavior & feedback
ResponsesInList.Text: In the Question itself, there is an option to include grade information, as well as general feedback to students. General feedback only appears once student has submitted the item. For example, we include a copy of our grading rubric for students to see. You could include insert the model recording here so that students can listen to it after having submitted their quiz. This feature, of course, has nothing to do with Poodll, just a normal possibility for providing feedback in Moodle.

ResponsesInList.Title: Student self-grading poodll quiz questions
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, Does anyone know of a way that I can set up a PoodLL quiz question that students can self-grade. Student reads a question Student records an answer with PoodLL Student compares their own answer to a model answer in "general Feedback" Student grades their answer (so the Teacher doesn't have to") Steps 1 through 3 are obviously already standard quiz steps. The fourth is important for me since the objective of the exercise I'm trying to build is the checking of the answer (and not necessarily the answering). I realize this is probably a general Moodle question rather than PoodLL specific, but since I got no answer in the general Moodle forums, I thought maybe another PoodLL user had experienced the same need.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Student self-grading poodll quiz questions
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Daniel, It depends on which version of Moodle you are using and even then would need testing to make sure you have things set up right. I have tried this with an essay question and a PoodLL question in a quiz, and it works. Create the quiz, then in Quiz administration click on Permissions . Scroll down to Activity: Quiz and find Grade quizzes manually . Click the + and add Student . In my testing, students were able to see and grade only their own quiz. The teacher was able to see and grade them all.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Student self-grading poodll quiz questions
ResponsesInList.Text: It works! Thank you. I've been trying to find out how to do this for ages. I'm very happy.  This will add a great deal of value to the activities I want to use it in and for the students on my course. Thank you.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Student self-grading poodll quiz questions
ResponsesInList.Text: Off hand, I can't remember which version of Moodle it was where they gave us the capability to modify the permissions for individual activities like this. The nice thing is the same "trick" of changing permissions for an activity works with other activities too, but you do have to be VERY CAREFUL as they do not necessarily limit a student to seeing and grading ONLY their own entries. Just as a personal reminder, on the few occasions that I've used this trick, I have added something to the activity name and description, such as "Self graded" just to make sure I don't accidentally duplicate and use it when and where I shouldn't.

A very good afternoon to you all and thank you for your support of Poodll. I'm wondering if anyone might be able to help me. Some students created a Poodll video with their ipads which converted properly and was visible when the students posted it to a forum (Moodle 3.2). I saw the video playing. However, now it isn't visible. All that shows in the forum window is "upfile_468814434.mov". In the html I can see "

" which means it should be showing doesn't it? If someone could point me to what I'm doing wrong and how to fix it I'd be most grateful. Kind regards, Eric

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Poodll video created with ipad not showing in computer browsers
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Eric As a super Poodll 3 guy you can, and probably should, send support requests via the contact form at https://poodll.com/contact or send email directly. The reason is that in Poodll 3 there is a support info file that you can generate. That tells me all your versions and settings, and it speeds things up. Find that at: site admin -> plugins -> filters -> poodll -> support info ( I think its probably best not to attach it to forum posts. ) To answer your question. It sounds like "cloud recording" is off. In that case the mov file has not been sent to the Poodll cloud conversion service. So it is stuck a mov file. Try turning on "cloud recording" on the Poodll filter general settings page. This is really the best thing to do. You could maybe play ,mov file back as is.  As long as the player selected was good with mov files. You could try the Media Element Video player in Poodll. This page explains how to set up Video JS, but the principles are the same for Media Element Audio. https://poodll.com/poodll-3-docs/video-js/ Finally there is a Poodll App these days. Read about that here, https://poodll.com/poodll-3-docs/using-the-poodll-mobile-app/ That makes it easier to record audio/video off iOS devices. But it also works best with cloud recording. So you should have that enabled.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Audio/video file remove from course but file still exist in MoodleData folder and info in Database
ResponsesInList.Text: If the files are stored in the Moodle file system, using the Moodle files API then Moodle should take care of deleting old files. This should happen periodically when the Moodle cron job is run.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Audio/video file remove from course but file still exist in MoodleData folder and info in Database
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you Justin for quick reply. Question is: How Moodle will understand which file to be deleted and which file should keep?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Audio/video file remove from course but file still exist in MoodleData folder and info in Database
ResponsesInList.Text: Each file is stored in a file area that is associated with a context . So for example, when an assignment submission is deleted, any files in file areas associated with that context and item id are deleted (or marked for deletion). So if you save files in the way that Moodle expects , Moodle will handle all that stuff for you.

ResponsesInList.Title: Usability Issues with PoodLL
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello we have just installed a number of PoodLL plugins on our moodle development environment in hopes of replacing nanogong and have seen some weirdness. We are running moodle 3.0.5+ on RHEL 6 with postgres DB We have installed the following PoodLL plugins: Filter ( 2.8.6(Build 2016061600)) Recording ( 2.6.0(Build 2015121100)) Assignment Submissions ( 1.5.9 (Build 2015121101)) Feedback ( 1.0.6 (Build 2015121101)) I noticed a number of warnings in the error log: [Wed Aug 17 16:42:40 2016] [error] [client x.x.x.x] File does not exist: /ROOT-DIRECTORY/moodle/mod/assign/skinvolumemeter.png, referer: https://SERVERNAME/moodle/mod/assign/view.php [Wed Aug 17 16:42:40 2016] [error] [client x.x.x.x] File does not exist: /ROOT-DIRECTORY/moodle/mod/assign/plainskinbackground.png, referer: https://SERVERNAME/moodle/mod/assign/view.php Is there some configuration issues we missed? Also, when we attempted to submit an audio assignment, the recorder would appear, the audio would be recorded and could be listened to but when submitted, the recorder showed up again on screen and the page was still loading (spinning).  I noticed a brief glance of some debug information and realized that moodle was set to debug email sending.  If I stopped the page, and went back to view the assignment, the audio was uploaded and working (blue flow player).  When I turned the debug off, it appeared to work. Also, for some reason, a tester indicated that they were unable to use the recorder but then it started working.  I know this is minimal information but is it possible that cache needed to be cleared or permissions for player needed to be accepted? Any advice would be appreciated.  If I have more additional comments, I will add them. Thanks Eric

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Usability Issues with PoodLL
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Eric Sorry for the slow reply. Those error messages about .png files can be ignored and they are annoying. I think I removed those in the latest version. The other issues are a bit hard to pin down. Sometimes debug and other output can get mixed up in what should be meaningful ajax responses and even into the recorded files themselves. Of course this shouldn't really happen but I have seen it before. I would consider this not a likely cause of the other problems you reported. There are many ways recording can fail, let me count the ways The recording timed out during upload The user's mic device is not recognized or not available The user has not given permission via various popup dialogs to access mic device The recording can't be uploaded due to bandwidth or network issues There are file permission issues on the PoodLL files There is a bug in PoodLL somewhere There is not really a problem, but the user thinks there is The file is recording ok, but its in a format that can't be played back The PoodLL filter settings are to convert with FFMPEG but ffmpeg is not set up PHP security settings, mod-security or suhosin are killing the file upload And that won't be all of them. So its a bit of a minefield at times. Its most likely a permissions, network or device issue. Try really short recordings, and see if they work. If they do, and big long ones don't, then try using the red5 audio recorder (ie not the mp3 one).

ResponsesInList.Title: FFMPEG Issues with Poodll/Moodle 3.0.2
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Community; I am struggling to get consistent and good performance out of Poodll/Moodle specifically regarding mobile uploads of video assignments. I am evaluating Poodll in a self hosted virtual instance of Moodle, and have found that although small mobile video files under 10MB will generally upload via Poodll and play back without issue on the source device, once the file size exceeds roughly 15-20MB, then things start to fall apart. Background... My use case requires that all students will be submitting assignments via mobile device platforms, which if I understand correctly would be best served by converting submissions via FFMPEG for widest mobile platform compatibility. Therefore, I have built FFMPEG on my test server from sources, and have verified that when called from the system path, it is working correctly. I have also verified via shell command that the FFMPEG switches used on the poodll demo site are working. Therefore, I assume that the Poodll Filter settings to auto convert mobile submissions to MP4 and to use FFMPEG for the conversion are also working, although I have yet to determine how to verify this as I have not seen any entries in any server logs. Back to the problem at hand... Without FFMPEG settings enabled in the Poodll filter, files of any size, up to the server limit of 512MB, will upload from a mobile device without issue. Playback is choppy over mobile data, but plays smoothly via WiFi, suggesting that playback quality is bandwidth dependent. With FFMPEG conversion settings enabled in the Poodll filter, mobile uploads above approximately 15MB in size will cause a browser error on Chrome, or will simply never complete the upload process in Firefox . In Chrome, after selecting a mobile video larger than 15MB to upload, the progress bar never appears and within about 15 seconds Chrome will throw an "Aw, Snap! Something went wrong while displaying this webpage..." error. In Firefox, after selecting a mobile video to upload larger than 15MB, the progress bar will appear, but no indication of upload activity will be evident and the process never completes. Obviously, in both cases Mobile uploads will fail. Since it is possible to turn on the mobile upload processing error, and turn it off, by enabling and disabling the FFMPEG conversion settings in the Poodll filter, I assume that the root issue is with the filter and not my environment, but I would appreciate some other perspectives or troubleshooting  suggestions on the matter. Moodle is running on a Debian (Jesse) instance, with 2GB of RAM, 60GB HD, and PHP.INI settings that allow up tp 512MB uploads and 640MB of script memory. Regards; Michael

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: FFMPEG Issues with Poodll/Moodle 3.0.2
ResponsesInList.Text: Michael Make sure that transcoding is going on in the background (there is a switch for that on the settings page). This will mean that the browser won't wait for the transcoding to finish. It relies on cron to kick off the transcoding. So it won't start till cron runs. Though it does sound like the real issue is with uploading. There are settings that affect uploads on your web server. Apache mod_security and the PHP extension suhosin are two of those. I would look into that. Both of those by default limit the size and nature of uploads.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: FFMPEG Issues with Poodll/Moodle 3.0.2
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you Justin; I have tried mobile submissions with the Background trans-coding option enabled and disabled, with no noticeable difference. So I will enable it again, but as you suggest the problem is likely to be elsewhere. I will investigate mod_security and suhosin. Hopefully I can find some clues there. Regards, Mike Somerville

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: FFMPEG Issues with Poodll/Moodle 3.0.2
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Justin; I guess I should have known this already, but Suhosin and Mod_Security are not installed on my Debian virtual server. Can you think of any other areas/log files that I can inspect to continue troublshooting?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: FFMPEG Issues with Poodll/Moodle 3.0.2
ResponsesInList.Text: Sorry Michael, I will reply to your email today. I apologize for the delay. It sounds like you are hitting some sort of upload limit. The usual suspects are suhosin and mod_security. In php.ini there are also: memory_limit upload_max_filesize post_max_size Apparently the values of those should follow this pattern: upload_max_filesize =< post_max_size =< memory_limit So the simple way is to make them all the same, but upload_max_filesize should never be greater then post max_size, which should never be greater then memory_limit. I am not an expert in this, though I have learned the hard way about some of it. Another thing you might try is recording over at https://demo.poodll.com . This is using the new PoodLL3 and Amazon S3 for uploads. If that all works for you, perhaps PoodLL3 would be a good solution

ResponsesInList.Title: PoodLL 3 will be a premium set of plugins
ResponsesInList.Text: After a fair bit of consideration I recently made the decision that PoodLL 3 will be a premium set of plugins. i.e. it won't be free. PoodLL has had great uptake from the Moodle community and the users have been positive through the good times, and patient and understanding through trouble times. So going premium is not something I have taken likely. At its heart is the reality that PoodLL needs a lot of work to make the full transition to HTML5 and for a host of other feature improvements and better support options (incl. documentation). You can read more on an this here: http://poodll.com/?p=2107 It will be available as an annual subscription with 3 tiers of membership: i) individual teacher (aka little guy) ii) single institution/organization iii) partner The pricing and some other details are yet to be decided, but from now on there will be more no more updates published on Moodle.org or the existing GitHub repositories, other than bug and security fixes. In the past I maintained a mailing list of PoodLL users, but these days that list doesn't contain the large majority of users. So currently there is no direct way for me to communicate with the PoodLL user base.  It would be very helpful for me if as a PoodLL user you could take this quick 8 question survey. https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/63DJ529

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: PoodLL 3 will be a premium set of plugins
ResponsesInList.Text: Justin, I wish you well with this.  I am sure it will be a success, and I think such developments are inevitable, with or without what we may call "official" support from MoodleHQ. On a completely different but related matter, I was reminded of the thread earlier on plugins.  I am still of the opinion that alongside the plugin/premium ecosystem we have talked about, we need a "Givealittle" style option. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: POODLL issues on mobile and desktop

ResponsesInList.Title: Audio/video device for PooDLL: General question
ResponsesInList.Text: Just going through the documentation of PooDLL to try audio/video assignment. On PooDLL filter , under network setting, PoodLL host address(tokyo.poodll.com) server id, RTMP port, etc.  What are the main tasks of PoodLL host server? On audio/video recording, how it works?  Which audio/video devices the pooDLL filter use? Any documentation on this on the forum, or pooDLL site? Maadis

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Audio/video device for PooDLL: General question
ResponsesInList.Text: Its a pretty broad question. The audio/video server is a Red5 Server. It records direct from a flash recorder and saves the recording locally. Later Moodle download s the recording from there into the Moodle data directory. It is not used for audio recordings made from mobile devices, or the MP3 recorder. Those just involve the browser and Moodle.

ResponsesInList.Title: An error occured, your file has NOT been submitted
ResponsesInList.Text: Nobody likes to see this. But what should you check when it happens? Well first of all its a general error. And it tells you/the student that your recording will not be saved. That is important. At this point your recording is already gone. There is probably nothing you can do but re record. Things to check i) is the microphone capturing sound? Or the video camera capturing your picture. If not, then there is nothing to submit or convert. And you might get this error. ii) does a very short recording get submitted ok? Sometimes longer recordings have problems at the server or browser level. iii) what recorder are you using? The two audio recorders look similar but are completely different. The video one is different again but in terms of troubleshooting its identical to the red5 audio recorder. MP3 recorder: recordings get less reliable as they get longer. Best not to venture over 2 mins. conversion to MP3 happens before the upload . If the file is too big it might spin forever and give up if the upload begins but throws an error, the connection to the Moodle server is problematic. Check the browser console for errors related to the file being posted. Some servers restrict the upload file size. Thats a whole new ball game, but if thats the case small uploads will be working. audio recorder/video recorder (red5): if you can't play it back after recording.... then the file never arrived on the Red5 server. Check the connection lamp on the recorder. Should be green. If its red or yellow your connection is bad (firewall? ) or the red5 server is down (happens.) If you can play it back, but get the error message above ... then the problem is that your file can't be collected from the Red5 server and copied back into Moodle. Turn off auto convert to mp3/mp4 in the filter settings and try again (or uncheck the mp3/mp4 checkbox on the recorder BEFORE recording). If conversion is the issue then its best to set up FFMPEG on the Moodle server and have PoodLL do its magic with that. Check the port settings in the PoodLL filter settings for HTTP. Your Moodle server will need to be able to do a server to server connection to that port on the  Red5 server to pick up the recorded file.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: An error occured, your file has NOT been submitted
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Justin, I have a student who claims the PoodLL MP3 recorder does not pick up his microphone (which, he claims, works fine otherwise). He can save recordings, but they have zero length and thus do not play. He claims to have tried different browsers, different microphone settings and has the latest version of Flash. Can you give a suggestion as to what I might look into. The others in the course manage to record. Rgrds, Paul.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: An error occured, your file has NOT been submitted
ResponsesInList.Text: I think your student has probably unwittingly denied permission to the recorder to access the microphone. Depending on the browser there are two places permissions need to be granted. Flash will show a permissions dialog which can be reshown by right clicking over the recorder and selecting "settings" or "properties". Chrome and other browsers may have their own permissions dialogs which will be shown after flash tries to access the mic. Other things to check might include that the microphone is plugged in, or if there are multiple microphones in the machine, that the correct one is selected. (again right click ->settings and choose the microphone tab ). Occasionally it is necessary to mess with the microphone tab settings there to spark the microphone into action. I do not know why. Flash is a black box in that regard.

ResponsesInList.Title: PoodLL audio recording cuts off early
ResponsesInList.Text: I've been using the PoodLL mp3 audio recorder in the Atto text editor on my Moodle 2.9 system and the recording seems to go fine. I save it and whenever I go to play it back, I usually only get an audio clip of 4 to 12 seconds long, even if the recording was a minute or two. Does anyone have any suggestions or solutions?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: PoodLL audio recording cuts off early
ResponsesInList.Text: I have seen this before, and I am trying to recall what caused it. It may be a PHP thing called Suhosin interfering with your uploaded audio data. Go to site admin -> server ->php info. Do a search (ctrl + f) for 'suhosin' and also look at 'post_max_size' and 'upload_max_filesize.' If suhosin is there, it is the most likely culprit. And you will need to configure it to accept larger upload sizes. If its not there, then its nor the problem. If either of the other 2 values are really small, ie less than 2M, then that might be the problem. But thats unlikely.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: PoodLL audio recording cuts off early
ResponsesInList.Text: I checked to see if suhosin was there but it's not. The post_max_size and upload_max_filesize are both 1024M. It's strange because the video recorder for example works perfectly. I've recorded up too 3 minutes of video and it all comes up when it's saved.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: PoodLL audio recording cuts off early
ResponsesInList.Text: The Video and Red5 audio recorders work very differently to the MP3 recorder. So its not so surprising the behaviour is different. The MP3 recorder posts the data to the server, which the other recorders don't do. Something is truncating the uploaded data. I am not sure what is doing it, but anything that limits the upload file size would be something to look at. If it works for you, you might try using the Red5 audio recorder as a workaround

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: PoodLL audio recording cuts off early
ResponsesInList.Text: I'll give the Red5 recorder a try but I seem to remember a similar problem with it. When you say server, do you mean the tokyo.poodll.com server? Do you think installing FFMPEG might help with this issue?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: PoodLL audio recording cuts off early
ResponsesInList.Text: Installing FFMPEG , and configuring PoodLL to use it, is a good thing to do. But that is really about file conversion. And I don't think that is a solution to this problem. Something is limiting the file upload size on your Moodle server. There is no "upload" from browser to Moodle server when using tokyo.poodll.com. The browser uploads to tokyo.poodll.com. And then your Moodle server downloads it from there. That is why it is unaffected.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: PoodLL audio recording cuts off early
ResponsesInList.Text: Ok, that makes sense. I'll talk to our Moodle host and ask them to investigate if there's something limiting the upload size. Thanks for your help Justin, it really is a great plugin.

One of the biggest problems is that it was very confusing for students because they couldn't tell if their audio actually submitted, as no notification was given, and after saving, they can't see the file there, or listen back to it. The instructor had the same problem in leaving voice feedback for students. Is there anyway for students and instructors to listen to files after they've been submitted? Or for instance if an instructor uses PoodLL to give feedback and two weeks later wants to hear it to remember what they said can they? Currently that doesn't seem available.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: PoodLL Issues
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Clint That should certainly be possible. I wonder how you are doing these things. Perhaps you are doing it a different way than most, or the recording is not working at all. The recorder does allow you to playback the recorded file, and should display an "uploading" dialog. And after the page hosting the recorder has been saved, there should be a player (audio or video) in the feedback area for the student ( or on the submission summary if its an assignment submission). And when the teacher returns to the page they should see a recorder for re-recording and a player for listening to the existing feedback recording. If none of that is happening, it should be, and so there is some problem at your end.

ResponsesInList.Title: Community Feedback on Poodll Accessibility?
ResponsesInList.Text: Our program is considering the Poodll Plug-ins, and one critical requirement we have of our coursework is accessibility . I am interested in the community's feedback on Poodll's usability and functions for people who are visually or hearing impaired. Putting aside the complications of audio and video assignments and feedback for a moment (we know we have a lot of work to help class members and instructors provide accessible content for each other ), please comment on the usability of the tools themselves. From the videos I am seen of Poodll in action the buttons and links appear as accessible or inaccessible as any other Moodle module.  Do you or your users report a different experience? Thanks for your thoughts. Robin Sitten Perkins eLearning

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Community Feedback on Poodll Accessibility?
ResponsesInList.Text: Robin, it would be interesting indeed to see what others have to say on this. But I have to say that it is probably not the best news. I battled for some time to make the buttons visible to screen readers and in the end found that it was not going to work ... because of limitations of the framework I originally wrote the recorders in. Though it did not occur to me then, since that time I have found a way around those limitations and have implemented it in one of the recorders. Basically by hiding the flash widget and handling all user interaction via html buttons and javascript a far more accessible interface can be made. Effectively we are introducing skinning to PoodLL. It is just a matter of finding the time, to get it all done. But accessibility goes beyond just screen readers, so any comments or advice would be welcome.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Community Feedback on Poodll Accessibility?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Robin, I was just browsing information about Poodll on Moodle.or and found your post and one other which didn't seem to address the issue. I've been working on Poodll in Moodle 2.8 and found that this plugin is not accessible. When I ran the NVDA screen reader and also sent a sample to our disability officer which is blind, he was unable to detect the player. The screen reader bypasses this alltogether. I will be sending a request to the developers to review this plug in and help us to comply with WCAG 2.0. Cheers, Nora Colazzo

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Community Feedback on Poodll Accessibility?
ResponsesInList.Text: You are right that much of it is not accessible. Luckily its not far away for the most popular of the components however. I was able to introduce full skinning for the MP3 audio recorder last month, thanks to "The Learning Factory" in Brazil. That makes adding accessibility to the MP3 recorder relatively simple. The other recorders require similar work, but at least we have a pattern to go with. The part that is not simple in all this for me, is exactly what the normal/desired behaviour of an screen reader, especially when it encounters an audio recorder. I was quite puzzled when I was testing with JAWS previously.

ResponsesInList.Title: PoodLL and Flash
ResponsesInList.Text: Yesterday Adobe Flash was getting death threats from Facebook and getting blocked by Firefox , after news of not just security errors, but in the wild exploits,  came to light. PoodLL uses Adobe Flash mainly for audio/video recording, but it can be turned off if need be. Flash can also be turned off for the widgets, players and whiteboards. Information on how to do that is here: http://poodll.com/flash-and-poodll/ In short, in the PoodLL filter settings, widgets, players and recorders can be limited to HTML5 only in the "When to use HTML5" section. The default whiteboard can be selected in the "Whiteboard settings" section. N.B. The non flash whiteboards (LiterallyCanvas and DrawingBoard.js) are not working properly in Moodle 2.9 yet. I am not actually advising anyone to turn Flash off. I will leave that to people more knowledgeable than me. But if you are in a situation where you cannot use Flash, the above settings should do the job.

(login creds are on the front page ) If it works there, it is a server specific thingy we need to figure out. There might be an error in your logs. If you can find the error log that apache generates, check it and see if there are any recent errors that look related. It can be necessary to turn off or configure a thing called Suhosin. And your server's maximum file upload size could also be a part of the problem. If we are at this point and there is no good error in your server logs, it gets quite complicated unfortunately. If it doesn't work on demo.poodll.com I think that maybe PoodLL has in issue with receiving uploads from your ipad. One thing that I have seen occur, is when people select "choose existing video" from the popup dialog, rather than "take a video." The uploaded file is compressed and this can cause problems with the browser/server interaction. The best reply right now to this is to recommend people select "take a video."

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Poodll on ipad
ResponsesInList.Text: I know that this is very late (happened upon it while reading about Poodll), but the upside-down video may just be that the ipad/iphone was being held "upside down" when taking the video. My understanding is that the camera has a definite orientation (Home button should be either down for portrait orientation or on right for landscape), but will flip the preview of the video or photo if held upside down. This flipping will continue if viewing the photo or video on an Apple device. When viewed on other systems - that don't read or understand the encoded "flip this image" instructions, the image is displayed as it was recorded - upside down. This became more of a problem when Apple enabled the volume buttons to act as the shutter release. This made it more natural to hold the phone with the shutter release (volume) on top - like a camera. Which is really upside-down. David

After I upgraded, bingo it all worked again. http://stackoverflow.com/questions/25790873/uploading-files-over-http-fails-on-ios-8-0-0-gm-safari So that is another thing to check when you have iOS uploading woes.

General questions: When using the HTML5 recording for audio, the Red5 server isn't needed, correct? It's up to the device to provide a file of type audio, and if FFMPEG conversion is installed/configured, that's what translates an ogg or wav to mp3? Is audio likely to be problematic for iPads in the way Eric was experiencing in the other thread? Thanks!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: HTML5 audio input - specific issue, general questions
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Hilary. Yes, you are pretty much correct. Red5 is not used when recording with iPads and other mobile devices. The device usually has a "record now or choose an existing file" type of file upload dialog. That is out of our control. In the case of iOS there is no "record audio" option on that dialog. Just record video. And yes, that means it is hard to predict the file type that will be arriving, though in the case of iOS it is .mov. FFMPEG does the conversion if it is installed and configured. Most PoodLL/Moodles don't have it installed I suspect. Is Audio likely to be problematic, as in Eric's experience. All I can say is "maybe."  As I said in that thread, I now feel that the file upload approach, at least in the way that I have implemented it, is too fragile. The possibility of a student having a device I have not tested on, or sending up a file that doesn't convert, or that doesn't make it through the upload , is quite real. I hope to re work things in the very near future, but for now I think we should assume that recording with mobile devices needs to be handled carefully.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: HTML5 audio input - specific issue, general questions
ResponsesInList.Text: Well. That is interesting. If the mov files convert to mp3 correctly. We would expect that the ogg and amr files should also. The conversion process is the same throughout PoodLL. So it is possible to do the testing for this outside the quiz. If you turn on "show download link beside players" in the PoodLL filter settings, a little download arrow will show beside the player. Even if you don't download, rolling your mouse over it should show you the url in your browser status bar. So you will see if it has in fact been converted by noting the file extension. PoodLL will first try to use the FFMPEG that it finds in the [Moodle]/filter/poodll directory. If it doesn't find one there, it will assume there is one available on the path and just bravely call "ffmpeg -i blahblah.flv blahblah.mp3" . So it is possible that the ffmpeg you are testing with and the one that PoodLL is using are not the same. It is also possible to set some parameters to the call to ffmpeg. The default is not to, but if you have some set and it might be that they work for mov but muff it for other filetypes. I have attached a document that I use to help people get up to speed with PoodLL and FFMPEG. See if anything in there helps. Also try it out on demo.poodll.com. If it works there, but not on your site, we might be able to see why. Justin

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Installing PoodLL
ResponsesInList.Text: Carl I replied to your email. But just for anyone else who might run into this. It is a pretty common pitfall. The PoodLL all file, after it is expanded contains four folders, they should be copied over the Moodle folders of the same name. Basically you are merging them. It is just a quick way to install all 6 mods. But you can just do it mod by mod, like this: i) poodll filter : [moodle]/filter - place "/filter/poodll" directory from zip ii) online poodll assignment(2.3/2.4) : [moodle]/ mod / assign / submission - place "/mod/assign/submission/onlinepoodll" directory from zip iii) poodll online assignment(2.2 ): [moodle]/ mod /assignment/type - place "/mod/assignment/type/poodllonline" directory from zip iv) poodll recording question : [moodle]/question/type - place "/question/type/poodllrecording" directory from zip v) poodll database field : [moodle]/ mod / data / field - place "/mod/data/field/poodll" directory from zip vi) poodll repository : [moodle]/repository - place "/repository/poodll" directory from zip I hope that helps.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Installing PoodLL
ResponsesInList.Text: I do not know why there is/was no uninstall link. To be honest, I have never really had to uninstall it. Anyway this seems to work. If you run this SQL (make sure your table name is correct) and purge caches, the message should go away. DELETE FROM `mdl_config_plugins` WHERE `mdl_config_plugins`.`plugin` = 'assignment_poodllonline'; NB: This is after you have removed any old PoodLL assignments, and removed the plugin from the filesystem.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: HTML5 audio player, mobile
ResponsesInList.Text: A possible problem is trying to play back the audio file from an https url . Mobile browsers (mobile safari in particular) can be quite fussy about the certificates they accept. demo.poodll.com is not using https. This would be the first thing that I would check. If you are not running https, then try to actually download that file and confirm that it is in fact an MP3 file. Then upload it to demo.poodll.com and try playing it back from there. If it works there but not on your site, it seems likely to be a server /poodll configuration issue. If it does not play back on demo.poodll.com then it is some sort if issue with the file or how it is created.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Path for recorded  video , audio file ....Please Help Me
ResponsesInList.Text: If you want to keep the recordings made with PoodLL you really need to do so in the context of an activity which can save submissions, ie an assignment (OnlinePoodLL Assignment Submission, or a quiz (poodll recording question) or a database activity (PoodLL Database Field). A page has no save button. So just inserting a widget won't leave the recording anyway. (At least not anywhere that is accessible. ) Although you can insert a recording widget in that way, you would only do so for activities where you didn't care to keep the recording. eg practising speeches.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Path for recorded  video , audio file ....Please Help Me
ResponsesInList.Text: Hmm. I suppose that didn't exactly answer the question. PoodLL saves the files using Moodle's file system API. So they go into the draft files area for the activity in question (NB a "page" has no draft files area when it is being viewed). When the activity is saved, the files are moved into the file area for that activity and submission. It is quite complex and you would need to read up on it all here: https://docs.moodle.org/dev/File_API Unfortunately there is no easy to find location on disk. As for generating a list of students, I can't answer that in a sentence. It is not really clear what you are trying to do. You should look to see if there is a plugin/report that does what you want.

ResponsesInList.Title: Stripping Video from iOS uploads
ResponsesInList.Text: Hey guys, Poodll is working great on my test server , and we're getting ready to deploy a few test rounds to replace our ageing cassette Language Lab. I have one concern/request. We are going to be using this primarily with mobile devices (though there are plans to also use the computer lab with it as well). Currently, mobile devices upload video to the system which is completely unnescessary for us. What I'm hoping for is a demux ability in poodll that I haven't seen before. Something that strips the video bitstream out of the file and leaves me with just the audio stored on the server. Is there a setting for this that I am missing, or is it currently not possible?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Stripping Video from iOS uploads
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Nelson. Yes it does that provided you have FFMPEG set up. See here: http://poodll.com/documentation/1.0/11/audio-and-video-conversion/ If you just put the ffmpeg file in the /filter/poodll folder and check the checkbox as on the documentation file, that should be enough. Make sure the ffmpeg can create mp3 and permissions are executable. I have a raft of notes and docs on this, so let me know if you get into trouble

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Stripping Video from iOS uploads
ResponsesInList.Text: The impression I'm getting from this is it's converting (reencoding) the audio stream, which I would rather the system not do (It's not all that powerful). Or is it demuxing the streams and I'm just misunderstanding? As far as I'm concerned, the final audio format isn't important, so much as just not wasting all that space with the video file attached and not burn resources on a relatively slow processor which has been commandeered for the purpose.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Stripping Video from iOS uploads
ResponsesInList.Text: It is set up to convert to mp3, so where the audio stream of the incoming file is not mp3, it will re-encode. With flv, you could just remove video and the remaining audio would play (as flv). I don't know how that would work with mov files though. There is the ability to specify encoding options for ffmpeg, there on the PoodLL filter settings page, but it does assume the end format will be mp3. In my own experience the conversion to mp3 is not a significant drag on the server, but it depends on how many conversions you have going on simultaneously. Related to this, I hope to implement background encoding sometime soon, so that the user doesn't have to wait for conversions to finish.

ResponsesInList.Title: Width of the pictures and videos

During Moodle plugin configuration phase I do get following error message: ---8<--- Debug info: Errors found in XMLDB file: Problem loading table assignsubmission_onlinepoodl, Some FIELDS previous/next values are incorrect Error code: ddlxmlfileerror Stack trace: line 349 of /lib/ddl/database_manager.php: ddl_exception thrown line 365 of /lib/ddl/database_manager.php: call to database_manager->load_xmldb_file() line 436 of /lib/upgradelib.php: call to database_manager->install_from_xmldb_file() line 1544 of /lib/upgradelib.php: call to upgrade_plugins() line 349 of /admin/index.php: call to upgrade_noncore() ---8<--- Any ideas what could cause this error? ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Installation of 'Online PoodLL submissions'-module fails in my Moodle 2.4.4 environment
ResponsesInList.Text: That is because I used the Moodle XMLDB editor to make the install. xml which creates the database tables and fields for the plugin. In Moodle 2.5 the need for specifying previous and next  fields was removed. See here: https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=262188 So while I previously had previous/next values, the XMLDB editor removed them. I have put them back now, for all the people stuck on pre Moodle 2.5 versions. Just navigate to your [moodle]/mod/assign/submission/onlinepoodll directory, and do a git  pull And you should get the fixes. Post back if you run into problems.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Installation of 'Online PoodLL submissions'-module fails in my Moodle 2.4.4 environment
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks a lot! After pulling your latest changes everything worked fine. Regards JP

ResponsesInList.Title: PoodLL Cheat Sheet
ResponsesInList.Text: Here is a cheat sheet of most (not all) of the PoodLL filter string types. I have been meaning to do this for *years* but rashly promised to do it today to a webinar. So it is done. Not all the options for each type are listed, but the main ones are. The URL is here: http://www.cheatography.com/justinhunt/cheat-sheets/poodll-filter/ The PDF download is attached to this forum post, but in the future you should get the latest from the url above. For those who don't know what this is all about, Poodll has a whole bunch of widgets that can be inserted into Moodle. eg a stopwatch. You do that by inserting a crafty little string that looks like this: {POODLL:type=stopwatch} which turns into stopwatch when you view the activity. The cheat sheet contains information about those crafty filter strings. You can play around, and see them, over at http://demo.poodll.com **NB DON'T COPY AND PASTE THE FILTER STRINGS** The encoding of the text on the PDF and cheatsheet website is wrong. Even without that, invisible html characters often sneak in and break things. Just type the strings out longhand. Enjoy *edited 19/06/2014 added warning about copy/paste and file encoding*

ResponsesInList.Title: Poodll plugin not working on MAC
ResponsesInList.Text: I have tested http://demo.poodll.com/ on MAC. The recording level indicator does not respond. It shows that a file has been created but not getting uploaded. The uploading process goes on and on, never stops. Please reply with a solution or an alternate of this. Waiting for a quick and positive reply.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Poodll plugin not working on MAC
ResponsesInList.Text: Sudeep Sorry for the slow reply. What browser are you using? And which recorder are you using? How long are your recordings? There are many things that can go wrong with recording. Most of them are at the browser end of things. Did you try rebooting and using a different browser? Google Chrome has a permissions dialog that is very hard to see. It pops up when you first try to use your webcam/mike on a site. It appears just beneath the address bar in the browser. Almost everyone misses it, even I forget about it. And of course there is the standard flash permissions dialog. If permission is not granted to the camera/mic then the recording will usually fail in the way you describe. Also if Skype or another application is trying to use the webcamera, it can be unavailable for the browser. Sometimes it happens that the other app doesn't release it. Even when the other app is closed down the camera is unavailable. I wonder in these cases if there is a problem with the driver software. I sometimes get this on my mac. Anyway, rebooting and trying a different browser are good steps to take. Finally depending on the recorder you are using, try not selecting "mp3" or "mp4" on the recorder. Sometimes the conversion process is failing because the server is too busy, or the recording too long, to respond before the browser gives up waiting. Justin

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Poodll
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Ann, Just like Al said really. If you have a clear idea of where you want to use it, then you could just download the modules you need. Most people probably don't use the 2.2 assignment type anymore or the database activity field(though you can do fun stuff with it) . So if you install piecemeal from Moodle.org, you might leave those off. The one mod you must have is the PoodLL filter. Everything else uses stuff from there. Stuff generally goes up on poodll.com earlier than on Moodle.org. But at the moment everything is up to date everywhere. Just to confuse things, there is a new mod, PoodLL Anywhere. It adds recording icons to the TinyMCE editor. If you use that you probably don't need the PoodLL repository anymore either. PoodLL Anywhere can be downloaded from the page you referenced, but it is not in the Kaboodle bundle or available from Moodle.org yet. Hmm, lets summarize this a bit PoodLL Add-on On PoodLL.com In Kaboodle On Moodle.org Notes PoodLL Filter Yes Yes Yes PoodLL Question Type Yes Yes Yes PoodLL Repository Yes Yes Yes PoodLL Assignment Submission Yes Yes Yes for new Moodle assignment (avail. from Moodle 2.3) PoodLL Assignment Feedback Yes Yes Yes for new Moodle assignment (avail. from Moodle 2.3) PoodLL Assignment Type Yes Yes Yes for old Moodle assignment PoodLL Anywhere Yes No No adds PoodLL icons to TinyMCE HTML area PoodLL Database Activity Field Yes Yes Yes

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Installing poodll
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi James, Yes, the PoodLL Filter has to be enabled for any of the other parts of PoodLL to work. It is located at Site Administration >  Plugins > Filters > Manage Filters. The PoodLL Filter Active should be set to On. The Apply to should be set to either Content or Content and Headings. You should also have it higher in the list than the Multimedia plugins filter, or you may see two players in some locations instead of just the PoodLL player. HTH , AL

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Installing poodll
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi James Just like Al and Howard said, the filter settings are at: Site Administration >  Plugins > Filters > Manage Filters And PoodLL in particular (once enabled) at Site Administration >  Plugins > Filters > PoodLL Filter It should actually work without the PoodLL filter being enabled , though that is not the usual setup. There are two main possibilities for this situation that are really just about learning how to use the Moodel assignment. ( I am assuming this is the new Moodle assignment (new as of Moodle 2.3). If you didn't know that there was an older version of the Moodle assignment, then you are probably ok. Since it should default to the new one.) i) did you configure PoodLL recording for the assignment submission? Or the assignment feedback? The assignment submission is what the student will do. The assignment feedback is how you respond to them. ii) Are you testing this by logging in as a student? By default a non student can't actually even do the assignment. So you have to be a student, then you will see a button saying "add submission" and it all starts from there. Justin

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Installing poodll
ResponsesInList.Text: Wonderful that sounds good. It is also nice to have them all in one room when you first do it, so that you can walk them through it. eg When the flash permissions dialog popups ... You can tell them what to do. If they record audio regularly the nervousness and pressure fade away, but the first few times it helps to take it slowly. So I might ask them to practice their speech/introduction a few times with different partners before they record. Also if you make the thing that they record basically a no brainer, eg say some tongue twisters, sing a nursery rhyme, or read a dialog from the book. That lowers the bar too. You will possibly run into technical quicksands the first time you do it. eg The browsers are too old, or half the microphones are broken . So it pays to do the activity yourself on the student machines first, so you know what will happen for them. Not doing this still catches me out sometimes. And making the first activity obviously not important ( some tongue twisters etc) means you won't get students too frustrated if things don't go right.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Installing poodll
ResponsesInList.Text: Mike, The first error relates to the portfolio export function, and looks like something I should fix. But I think it is not the problem you are having. The second error is occurring because there is no file to display. I think that is caused because your camera is not being picked up and the recorder is recording, but recording nothing. That still doesn't explain why only "feedback" is giving the problem. Before you commence recording, try checking both the device settings on the recorders settings tab, and the webcam settings on the flash properties page (right click the recorder). Can you select the webcam on either of those locations and cause the webcam light to light up? Justin

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Installing poodll
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Justin, I'm going to give you the best and worst news of all of IT.  It's working perfectly, I can't break it, I can't reproduce the problem, and I'm not sure what changed. Sorry about that. I have auto-update turned on in Moodle, I powered off&on my Laptop.  Not sure what else changed. But in any event, it's working just fine now. I can say it woks in the current version of Moodle, PooDLL, Windows 8,1 Chrome, and IE 11. So whatever the problem was, the answer is to update. ====================================== Again, thanks!  At some point, I'll configure FFMPEG and test further.  I'd like to take some of the workload off of your server. Thanks again for all you do!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Installing poodll
ResponsesInList.Text: The 'ol reboot did the trick perhaps. Or caching was somehow getting you. Anyway thats good news.

ResponsesInList.Title: Poodll repositories
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, I am not sure if this is the right place to post this or not. If not, please let me know. I would like to give faculty the ability to give and receive audio for feedback and assignment from within Moodle. We are running 2.5.2 (and plan to upgrade to 2.5.2 in a few weeks). Has anyone used any of these: https://moodle.org/plugins/browse.php?list=set&id=13 I am particularly interested in these for recording audio: https://moodle.org/plugins/view.php?plugin=repository_poodll https://moodle.org/plugins/view.php?plugin=assignsubmission_onlinepoodll https://moodle.org/plugins/view.php?plugin=qtype_poodllrecording Does anyone have any experience with these? Is there another you would recommend over these? Thanks!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Poodll repositories
ResponsesInList.Text: I have them on my system in work, and although they are not in widespread use yet (we upgraded to 2.5 ready for this term which started this week and Poodll was added as part of that upgrade) they work very well in all the testing I have done with them and look very easy to use. Richard

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Poodll repositories
ResponsesInList.Text: All PoodLL plugins are working very well in my Moodle2.4 and 2.5. The PoodLL should be included into the core. It will bring up Moodle to a super multimedia LMS. Go PoodLL!
